clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Physical Training on Bone Turnover and Quality of Life in Osteopenic Postmenopausal Women.

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of our research was to define both in vivo and in vitro whether and to what extent an high-impact exercise program would affect bone cell turnover and improve the QoL in osteopenic postmenopausal women.

detailed_description.textblock: Subjects were selected among those attending the "Bone and Mineral Metabolism Disorders" Clinic of Perugia University, Italy, since May 2nd 2015 and January 31st 2016. A total of 33 women (mean age 62,63+/-5,80) volunteered to participate in the study.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: This was an interventional, single group assignment study in which the subjects were first assigned to the control group and, after 1-month interval with no physical training, were shifted into the 3-months exercise intervention group. Thus, the subjects acted as their own control at the end of the study.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in markers of bone turnover from baseline to 4 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Measurements of bone turnover markers with the use of serum carboxy terminal telopeptide of collagen type I (sCTX), that is one of the most sensitive and specific bone resorption markers of osteoclast-mediated collagen degradation, serum procollagen type I N-terminal propeptide (sPINP) as the standard bone formation marker, and sclerostin acting on bone surface osteoblasts to inhibit their activity and promote apoptosis.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in markers of bone turnover from 4 weeks to 12 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Measurements of bone turnover markers with the use of serum carboxy terminal telopeptide of collagen type I (sCTX), that is one of the most sensitive and specific bone resorption markers of osteoclast-mediated collagen degradation, serum procollagen type I N-terminal propeptide (sPINP) as the standard bone formation marker, and sclerostin acting on bone surface osteoblasts to inhibit their activity and promote apoptosis.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in circulating osteoprogenitor cells (OPCs) from baseline to 4 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Measurements of circulating OPCs with stem cell characteristics (CD34+) and express bone-specific proteins such as alkaline phosphatase (AP +) and osteocalcin (OCN +).

primary_outcome.measure: Change in circulating osteoprogenitor cells (OPCs) from 4 weeks to 12 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Measurements of circulating OPCs with stem cell characteristics (CD34+) and express bone-specific proteins such as alkaline phosphatase (AP +) and osteocalcin (OCN +).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Health-related quality of life from baseline to 4 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Secondary outcome measure is the health-related Quality of Life using the Quality of Life questionnaire of the European Foundation for Osteoporosis (QUALEFFO).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Health-related quality of life from 4 weeks to 12 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Secondary outcome measure is the health-related Quality of Life using the Quality of Life questionnaire of the European Foundation for Osteoporosis (QUALEFFO).

arm_group.description: The exercise program was performed at C.U.R.I.A.Mo. Healthy Lifestyle Institute of Perugia University. The program provided 24 exercise sessions supervised by 2 physical education instructors and 2 medical researchers with a maximum attendance of 5 patient/group and carried out twice a week for three months. Each session lasted approximately 45 minutes divided into 15 minutes of cardiovascular activity performed using various ergometers and 30 minutes of weight-bearing endurance activities, resistance training and other exercise to develop balance and prevent falls, organized according to circuit training methodology. The great part of the exercise included in the program aim to provide variably strains (compression, bending, twisting) distributed across an higher surface of the femoral neck, to produce a maximal osteogenic response in bone.
Usual care and no additional physical exercise

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- postmenopausal
- bone mineral density T-score less than -1 but more than -2.5 in the total hip or lumbar spine (L1-L4) by dual energy x-ray absorptiometry
- be able to attend an exercise program 2 times per week over the 3-month period
- stated availability throughout the entire study period
Exclusion Criteria:
- secondary causes of bone loss such as osteomalacia, glucocorticoid medication
- co-morbidities that would interfere with participation in exercise such as severe heart or pulmonary disease, inflammatory joint disease, severe osteoarthritis, psychiatric condition
- physical or orthopaedic disabilities that would place the subject at risk or limit their ability to perform exercise
- a past vertebral fracture
- history of chronic diseases, such as renal, hepatic, cardiac, and rheumatic diseases
- current or prior use of drugs that could interfere with bone mass (i.e. glucocorticoids, antiresorptive drugs and hormonal replacement therapy)
